segments.text: First, would you discuss your academic training and how you became attracted to oceanography?
Oh, yeah.
I went to Allegheny College in Meadville, Pennsylvania.
Does the level look all right?
Yes, the level looks fine.
And I always thought I wanted to be a physicist so I wouldn't have to deal with many people.
It seemed to make a great idea.
I remember telling a friend of mine I was working with once, that's why I was going to be a physicist.
Then I worked for, after school I took a job with Magnaflux, which is a magnetic inspection system.
The fellow was an alumni from the school.
He happened to be back the June I was graduating.
He offered me a job, and so I took it.
It would be an hour, hour and a half.
And so I got a job.
They weren't too easy to find them.
So I worked for Magnaflux for about two years.
And I was thinking about going back to school.
I got married, and this is 1940, and I got married in 1941.
In fact, I went off to graduate school in

I got offered an assistantship, and then I felt I just wouldn't be able to survive with all the social and emotional problems, wanting to get married and getting $30 a month for being a graduate assistant and so on.
I went back to work for Magnaflux.
I stayed with them for two years, and by then the war had started, and I was going to join the Army, and they told me I should take this job at Lockheed.
expecting overseas.
I went over and worked in Ireland for a year at an Air Force base repairing airplanes.
And I came back in, I went into the Army, and then I got into the Navy and got out in 1946.
And we had lived in Chicago, in a very nice place to live, north of Chicago, Glenview.
I know you probably don't know that.
It was a very comfortable, nice little log cabin out in the country.
So we moved back there after the war, and I went over to Northwestern, and I
with a GI Bill applied and got in the physics department.
So I spent two years there.
And while I was there, Sam Goudsmit was there.
He was a fairly famous physicist.
I started doing my thesis work under him.
And then he moved to Brookhaven.
And I moved to Brookhaven in 1948 with him and finished my thesis there and started working on another thing and got my degree in 1949.
I stayed at Brookhaven two years, working on the time-of-flight mass spectrometer.
And I'd always wanted to teach, so we left Brookhaven and went to the University of Toledo, where I taught in the physics department for six years.
And during those summers, the first summer we stayed in Toledo, and the next two summers we went down to Los Alamos to work for the summer.
And the next summer, which is 1955,
asked me to come back to Brookhaven for the summer.
So I went back there and was working with him.
And this is how I got into oceanography, basically.
It's a sort of interesting story.
I was crossing a field, and a fellow was working.
The guy that does neutrino experiments was working on his equipment, and I went over to help him.
He was having sort of a bad day, and he said, we ought to go to a place like Woods Hole.
And where you have fun.
There's a lot of interesting problems.
And you get out and you sail around and see the world.
Really nice.
And I said, gee, that's a great idea.
Went back to work.
Then we went back to Toledo.
And the first physics of the day I picked up when I got home had an advertisement in it from Woods Hole asking about physicists.
So I wrote this fellow a letter saying, why don't you write too, and I'll write, and we'll see what happens.
And I wrote, and he didn't.
So we came the next summer in 1956 to Woods Hole, worked the summer.
Once we were on the Cape for a summer, why, we were hooked.
Convinced then oceanography was for you?
We were convinced oceanography was for us.
So really your Navy experience didn't have anything to do with it?
Very little, no.
Nothing at all, really.
My Navy experience had very little to do with ships.
It was an anti-submarine weapon, classified thing.
You know, it was...
Like most of the Navy, it doesn't have much to do with the ocean.
It's an inconvenience.
But a lot of oceanographers came to that, and he said, right?
Oh, yes, right.
Well, a lot of the people in the acoustics work, of course, were associated with the Navy, and it's sort of a natural thing to gravitate to, in a way.
When I came here, I thought I was really interested in doing some tracer experiments, using radioactive stuff, and so on.
I went to work for Brackett.
Hersey, and he was in acoustics, and so I started doing acoustics, and I've been there ever since.
It's just that simple.
And I assume that when you were at Los Alamos, you were doing primarily nuclear energy measurements, right?
Okay.
So it's really almost as if you're transferring fields to go into acoustics.
Yeah, really.
What was your reaction then to acoustics?
How did you choose it?
Well, it was the thing to do when we were here.
That was the
That was a big thing.
I came to work for Brackett, and that's what he was doing.
So that's what I started doing.
And I just never shook loose.
There was a lot of other interesting things to do.
Eventually, then, I got, while I was working for Brackett, we got involved with the Illuminat between Woods Hole
The Navy and Reynolds Metals.
Reynolds Metals was building a submarine called the Illuminat.
The Navy wanted to get in somebody into the deep diving business.
And it looked like by giving us the money, we could charter the, make a deal with Reynolds to run the Illuminat.
And we were looking for somebody to sort of run that program.
So I left acoustics at that time and took over that program.
and due to some problem in making a negotiation, why we didn't do business with Reynolds.
Instead, we got money from the Navy and built the Alvin.
So from 1961, approximately, until 1966, one of my major concerns was Alvin, getting it rented, the whole problem there.
In 1962, we formed departments.
And I became department chairman of applied oceanography.
So that was a break with the acoustics.
But then in 66, about 65 or 66, Hersey had become department chairman of geology and geophysics.
And the acoustics had stayed in there.
And in that time, when he left, I was sort of the logical one to take over that department.
So I became chairman of geology and geophysics
And I did that until 1969.
And I kept the applied oceanography for a year, and then Scott Dobbin came here, took over applied oceanography, and then changed the name to Ocean Engineering.
So this is sort of the department I had back in the early 60s, basically.
From 69 to 71, I went to La Spezia and was deputy director over there for two years, admittedly.
But when I came back, Scott Dobbin was leaving, so I became chairman of the ocean engineering department.
Jim Hertzler had taken on the department chairmanship of geology and geophysics, and I went to Las Vegas.
So it was all pretty simple.
Okay.
Well, let's sort of follow in order.
The new field, acoustics.
Okay.
What sort of experimentation were you involved in, and was this the first time you'd gone out to sea for any length of time?
Yeah, really.
I'd been on a ship.
I'd ridden a ship when I was in the Navy in some places, but nothing.
It's different.
You're almost a passenger, unless you're on the decan or something.
I was always a passenger, basically, because of the work we did.
So this is the first experiment in going to sea, right?
There wasn't any major upheaval.
I mean, I guess acoustics is physics.
Physics works.
It's interesting and complicated, but there wasn't anything.
There was a lot to learn, of course, because of the details and all of the problems and the approximations and where things work and where they don't work and why they do that.
You just have to learn that type of thing.
There wasn't anything fundamentally different from doing a lot of other things in a way.
Do you feel that to be a good oceanographer, you have to go to sea?
No, don't believe that at all.
Jules Verne was a pretty good oceanographer, I think.
I don't think he ever left a four or five block area to perish, as far as I know.
Well, I just wonder, because more and more, at least people in physics and oceanography go to sea less and less.
Yeah, well, that's true.
But then I think the world of oceanography is becoming more and more quantitative.
Analysis problems are getting much more important in the thing and not so much the exploration.
When people first went to see, they were just finding out what was there.
And I assume your first acoustical work was really just finding out what was there?
No, the first one, they had a pretty good program.
We got involved in some propagation work, which is you make noises and
listen some distance away, and you see how the sound is propagated through the water, and try to understand why it behaves the way it does.
People are still doing the same experiment, basically.
Different frequencies, different scales, and different places.
Who worked on this early acoustical work besides yourself?
Oh, well, this wasn't really early.
This was in the 1957, don't forget.
Oh, Percy, Alan Vine, Bud Knott, the local group here, Betty Bunce, Henry Johnson, Dick Backus.
We ran sort of a sideshow in some of the things.
We got on cruises, and we'd do propagation work.
Echo sounding was not very, it was just getting into its own at that time, and just knowing what the shape of the bottom light was.
It's beginning to be recognized as being more and more important and easier to do.
Started to do seismic profiling, which is a echo sounding where you look into the bottom to see what the layers are like.
This is the big tool that the oil companies use now all the time.
Bracket.
But not for two of the people who put this into sort of a routine production mode, you might say.
It's become a great big thing with the oil companies now, of course.
They've far surpassed what we do, just because they have so much more money to spend on equipment.
And we worked with people from Daystrom.
We worked with people from NRL, from New London.
We went out and looked at submarines.
You know, one of the problems you are is looking at echos from submarines.
How far can you see them?
Any problem?
No problem at all.
I just want to check and make sure we don't have any.
Okay.
And then we worked on propagation.
We did some ambient noise.
We did some bottom reflectivity.
Did a lot of volume reverberation with Dick Backus.
This is looking at the scattering back from little creatures in the sea.
A lot of these problems are still being worked on.
What's happened is the
Technology's changed so much.
You can do a lot more now easier than you could before.
The ideas haven't changed very much.
This is one of the interesting things that happens in most science, oceanography in particular.

If you look at acoustics particularly, if you look back in the early literature, you can see statements about doing things that they just couldn't do because they didn't have the technical capability that we do routinely now.
It's really very deep.
Yeah, and this is happening in all fields, of course.
Do you attribute this portion to a fallout from space technology?
Oh, it would have happened whether space technology was there or not, I think.
Because it accelerated some of the problems, I think.
But I think the big things have been development of the computer and the solid state equipment
It's just made everything better.
And I'm sure that would have happened anyhow.
I think the people weren't really worried about that in the Bell Labs when they developed the first transistors.
That's just put more money into it, really.
So you would judge, at least in your experience in oceanography, the computer and transistor to be the most important technical advances, or would you choose others?
Well, I think they are the most important technical advances.
Well, everybody's biased because of the particular thing he does.
Sure.
If somebody wanted to measure, well, even the people who measure currents would probably tend to agree with that.
Because you can build little things you can put out there that last a long time, use very little power, and store a lot of information.
That's the problem in a lot of these measurements.
I think that's reasonable.
Now, after doing acoustical work for really the first several years, what made you change to underwater technology?
Well, it just sounded like it might be fun.
Okay.
Simple enough.
Yeah, we were going to get this deep submersible, and nobody really, well, they had these bathyscaps, which were quite immobile, you know,
They can get down deep, but they can't move around much.
It just seemed like it'd be a nifty thing to do, to be able to build something that could get down and you could go around and look at things and take pictures and so on.
It turned out to be very successful, actually.
Although at first you received some criticism.
Well, it always does.
Well, when they came to you with the idea, what was your first reaction?
Which idea?
The idea of the submersible.
Well, we were already, Woods Hole was,
already somewhat committed to this line.
We were trying to negotiate this thing with Reynolds and through the Navy.
And I just happened to be talking to Bill Rainey one day about it.
And he asked me if I'd be interested.
You see, he came to be basically a pilot and one of the chief engineers on it.
We wanted somebody else to sort of head up the whole thing and do more of the interaction with other people and so on.
So he asked me if I'd be interested.
about it and said, yeah, sounds like an interesting thing to do.
I stayed active in some of the acoustics work during that time.
I went on quite a few different cruises that had nothing to do with the submarine.
But my major effort was on the submarine during that time for about four or five years.
That was my number one worry, I guess, is the best way to say it.
Was the number one worry attached to it in designing it or in raising money for it or what?
Just the mechanics of getting the thing designed, built, operating.
You know, there are a lot of unknowns in those things.
You get a lot of
critics or people who worry about different things.
A lot of them are justified, and each one they worry about, you have to look at and see whether it's real or not real.
Answer the question, go or no go, one way or the other.
It turned out that the hull, before we built the hulls, nobody had built hulls like that.
The hulls for the Bathurst calves are really overdone.
Well, we were really worried about weight, and we were trying to get down to reasonable thickness and yet still have a good safety factor.
Well, we had much discussion about the hulls and the design and the shape they were going to be and all this business.
Finally built them, and they turned out to be much better than anybody.
The tests on them showed they were much better than anybody had designed, thought they were going to be, which was sort of nice.
And there were just a whole host of problems like that.
And then you have the administrative.
I mean, the company building them had underestimated the cost, which is not unusual.
And part of it was certainly legitimate and honest.
And part of it just wasn't good management.
And when you run a business like this, you have to be a little bit hard-nosed.
You just can't give them everything that they want because they think they didn't make money or lost money on deals.
You have to run it as a business as well as a science.
So that took quite a bit of time.
And different ideas about things.
And then, of course, there's the first time you start testing it, first time you put people down and they go deep.
You have a lot of worries.
And we lowered it down on a big string down to 6,000 feet before we put anybody in it to go down that far.
And that was a very interesting week we did that.
had a million dollars hanging on the end of the string down there.
Okay.
In terms of design, first, and problems with design, except for the thickness of the hull, what seemed to be your next major problem?
What were you concerned about most in terms of design?
Well, it's the whole host of, not minor things, but a whole host of
things we'd never done before.
We wanted batteries, and we wanted to be able to drop the batteries in case a submarine gets hung up somewhere.
Why do you want to be able to drop the batteries?
Submarine gets lighter, and then it'll come to the surface.
And this took quite a bit, getting a decent package for the batteries.
We decided to use lead acid batteries, because even though they're not the most efficient, it turns out they're not too bad, and they're fairly economical.
We didn't have the least clue as to whether we were going to have to drop one set of these every month or every four months.
We've never dropped a set yet, it turns out.
And another problem we worried about was building the thing so that the whole sphere, the part with the people in it, could be released from the rest of it in case the rest of it got tangled up.
Then you hang up, and you can unhook the sphere, and the people come to the top, even with only half the submarine.
And getting that thing designed and so it worked right took a lot of problems, because it's under high stress, the release mechanism.
And the first one we built galled a little bit.
So it was just, again, stainless steel on stainless steel.
So we had to change that.
Every one of those steps.
You find out about it, and then you have to change it.
It's an agony.
Who consulted with you on the design and the design problems?
Well, we had a fellow, Bud Froelich, who really originated the design out in, he was working for General Mills at the time.
And he was, the people there were very good.
The engineering group there were really quite good on it, worked hard, did a good job.
And we talked, of course, we were being,
Because we were spending Navy money, we were being monitored by the Navy all the time.
We consulted with them, and then we had a different set of relations with different groups in the Navy, some very encouraging and some a little discouraging.
We had minor flare-ups with different people who thought this just wouldn't work this way or something like that.
No big deals, but each one good for a week or so.
Did your money, did they become O&R?
Yeah, O&R, right.
A fellow named Swede Momsen, who was the son of the Momsen and the Momsen Lung.
He really pushed the thing, couldn't he?
Really good.
That way was fine.
But the motors, the drive motors were a problem because they had to run in oil.
You know, down at these pressures and everything has to be pressure correlated and then we had the
You have to be able to change the, essentially change the volume of the submarine so you stay neutral when you're floating down there.
That was rather interesting.
That worked fine.
We've since changed that system.
We now have a, we've pumped saltwater, seawater in and out of some spheres now in the album the way she is now.
Well, the biggest problem was a little one with the,
When we made the first 6,000-foot test, we had trouble with the main propulsion in the steering motors.
And this cost us about three months of work before we found out what the problem was.
You get down and dive, and you get down to 2,000 or 3,000 feet.
And sometimes these things would want to stay running, even though you turned them off, or else they wouldn't run when you turned them on.
And eventually, we found that some contacts
They're opening up in oil.
You see, all the electrical system was in oil.
So the relays were in oil, and they'd open up.
And when they did this, they're opening up and pulling an arc and forming little carbon granules in between the relay points.
Then this would either hold it open or partially short it out, and that's causing the problem.
So all we did was turn them this way, so when they made those carbons, they dropped down to the bottom, and that solved the problem.
That took us a long time.
Then we lost Alvin one time down off Bermuda, and we had a fairly rudimentary navigation system.
We could ping on them, and we could tell how far away they were from us by acoustics, but we didn't know which direction they really were.
But when we were working on a slope, they would just tell us the depth of water where they were on.
That drew a line for us, and then knowing how far away they were from us, knowing where we were, we could draw a line to tell us where they were.
And we went in.
We were out there, and we were just finishing a dive, and they were coming up.
We got a measurement on them, and then we had to make up our mind whether we went this way or this way.
And you change the range, and you know whether you're going the right way or not.
We went this way, and the range got longer.
So we went back this way, and we never heard them again.
By that time, they'd come up through the water, and we couldn't hear them.
And we didn't know where the heck they were.
So we spent about eight or 10 hours
before we finally found them.
They shot some flares up.
We got the Coast Guard planes that came out from Bermuda to start looking.
They waited until it really got dark, and then they shot some flares up.
And we saw them and went over and picked them up.
And that was interesting.
I bet it was.
I bet it was interesting for them, too, by the way.
Yeah, right.
Yeah, they could see the lights of Bermuda and nothing else.
We had trouble with the radio, though.
The other thing that screwed us up there,
antenna on their radio developed a crack, and it shorted it out, so they couldn't transmit back to us.
And we were calling them, and they couldn't, they could just barely hear us calling them, but they couldn't get back on the air to tell us anything.
So that was just another interesting day.
We built, the mothership was an interesting, difficult problem to solve.
We built Lulu eventually.
We really didn't know what to do about Mothership, because nobody had really been handling the submarine this big before.
And we found out that there were two of these big hulls down at New London.
They'd been used in some mine towing, mine warfare experiments that were available.
And they were about 100 feet long, elliptical shape, 9 feet high, and 14 feet wide, each hull.
And we could get those, so we decided we'd build them.

catamaran the way we do Lulu now there's a picture of it right there the way we do Alvin you see we pull her in between those two hulls then we have an elevator that's underneath her and picks her up so you can work on her so we designed that ship and built it and it was put together down here at the town dock as a matter of fact it was pretty casual in a good manner it's still working it's sitting out it's right out at the end of the dock today as a matter of fact
It's been modified.
It's changed.
It looks different than it did in that picture.
Somewhat now, it's got some bows on it and so on.
But it's still basically the same halls that we put on.
And the first year, we were very, it looked like a disaster.
We didn't have the bridge or anything.
We just had a, you know, we were just feeling our way along, playing it cool.
So we got it running, and it's run quite well ever since, actually.
When I became chairman of the geology and geophysics department, I gave up Alvin, and Scott Dobbin became its father, because it stayed in the applied oceanography department.
Then I got it back again when I came back in 1971.
That's been a lot of fun.
Was there anything in the first series of tests you ran up on Alvin beside the flexibility of the hull which surprised you, or the strength of the hull?
Not really.
You didn't anticipate it all in turn?
Everything seemed to be pretty well.
It ran about the way we thought it would.
Well, you know, a lot of engineering went into it.
Bill Rainey was very important in it.
Jim Maverick, everybody worked really hard on it.
Arnold Chart.
We had a lot of people working on it.
Where did the oven go on its first voyage?
Our first really working voyage, we went over and found the bomb in Palomares.
That was the first time we ever, well, that's almost true.
We tried to do some work off Bermuda the year before, but we didn't have that one problem 100% solved.
So we came back.
We felt we'd solved the problem in Palomares.
guess it was 65, finally, when we were at Bermuda, and we came home, and we tore it down and looked at everything, and we were just putting it back together when the bomb happened.
So that was the real first test of being, you know, thinking we were an operational submarine.
And that was just hard work.
What do you think has been the Alvin's contribution to, let's say, applied oceanography?
Well, I've applied oceanography.
I don't think it's done a great deal.
It's done a lot more in geology, geophysics, and biology.
We've done a few tasks, mostly for the Navy, that are applied tasks, going finding some things they've lost or looking at certain things for them.
That's been a chore, a job, and it hasn't been really very exciting.

I think the things they've done in the Mid-Atlantic Ridge, the famous work, anywhere along where they've gotten down into these canyons and really got much more of a feel for what the bottom of the ocean is like in a coherent manner.
Even with photographs, it's difficult.
Photographic technique has evolved very nicely in the last ten years.

But to get down there and be able to look at the bottom and then selectively sample and see how the things relate to each other really tells you a lot more about the bottom than people ever knew before.
The stuff they did in Famous has really been very interesting in terms of seafloor spreading and things like that.
That's been the big thing.
In biology, they've learned quite a bit.
They've been able to do some experiments on the bottom that they weren't able to do before.
And of course, set up a whole new
venture of research for some people here, Holger Janisch, and looking at sort of the biological slowdown, the bacterial slowdown in depth.
When Alvin was dropped in 68, I guess it was, she went to the bottom because a couple of cables broke.
There were no people there, fortunately.
And she stayed down there for nine months before she was recovered.
And the sandwiches and apples that were in there looked very much like new sandwiches and apples when they came back up.
There'd been very little bacteria action.
So Holger Janischer has been really looking at that problem to a large extent as part of his work ever since.
He's finding out some very interesting things.
